div.head: Chauncey B. Tinker (1876-1963)
div.p: Tinker was a memorable teacher of eighteenth- and nineteenth-century English literature at Yale University from 1903 to 1945, and served as keeper of rare books for Yale University Library starting in 1930 or 1931, and remained in that post for some years beyond his retirement from teaching. A collector himself, Tinker was known for his generosity in opening his personal library of manuscripts and rare books for students' use (Pathak, “Chauncey Brewster Tinker”, 278-81; Metzdorf, The Tinker Library, viii).

Tinker, who had always been a zealous advocate for building the library's collections, was just beginning his formal duties as keeper of rare books, when Ruskin collectors and scholars on both sides of the Atlantic were surprised by the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1930 and the Sothebyʼs Sale of Ruskin Manuscripts and Library, 1931. Documentation has not been found of Tinker's role in Yale's significant acquisitions from these sales, which were mediated primarily though not exclusively through the agency of the Boston dealer in rare books and Ruskin collector, Charles E. Goodspeed (1867–1950), but it seems unlikely that this significant investment could have gone forward without Tinker's championship.

The Sotheby's sales exactly coincided with the overwhelming project of constructing the new Sterling Memorial Library (1927-31). While additional acquisitions to be housed in the library's new rare book room must have competed for the attention of library administrators, much less for available funding, the peculiar relevance of acquiring Ruskin materials would not have been lost on Tinker. At the heart of the university, Yale was completing vast neo-Gothic library, which blended cathedral- and cloister-like architecture for its entryway and reading spaces, symbolizing veneration, with skyscraper-like architecture for the bookstacks. The architect, James Gamble Rogers, was determined to preserve "religion, or at least a version of it, at the Yale center, by creating a new kind of sacred space for the modern American university--a cathedral library laden with quasi-religious iconography". The design not only "placed the functions of a modern library within the shell of a neo-Gothic cathedral", but also incorporated an iconographic scheme that was perceived as important enough to sacrifice "six tiers of book stacks in order to fund more ornament" (Grubiak, “Reassessing Yaleʼs Cathedral Orgy”, 171, 174, 178; and for the iconographic program of the decorative scheme, see "The Sterling Memorial Library"). Ornament is central to Ruskin's writing about architecture.

While his scholarship was centered in Boswell and Johnson studies, Ruskin and the Pre-Raphaelites held an important place in his teaching, collecting, and writing. In 1908, he published Selections from the Works of John Ruskin, which he distanced from "such a volume as used to be entitled Elegant Extracts", instead anthologizing chapters and lectures in as complete form as practicable "to insure a correct notion of the general complexion of Ruskin's work", which he characterized as a unity and "one continuous development" in thought and style (pp. iii, xii, xix). His personal collection included five autograph letters; and his rare and first-edition printed Ruskin, while not aspiring to comprehensiveness, ranged widely across Ruskin's interests and rhetorical styles (Metzdorf, The Tinker Library, 371-74). He had access to a comprehensive Ruskin collection belonging his friend, R. B. Adam (1863-1940), a collection donated to Yale University Library in 1929.
Less happily, Tinker was Goodspeed's correspondent when the retired bookseller donated to Yale the Ruskin manuscripts salvaged from his house fire in 1941.
